author: Mark Broadbent
title: DEFI billing - an untapped market?
description: Consider the vast number of utilities & other Gov orgs that bill customers on a regular basis using expensive inflexible insecure solutions.

assessments.note: This proposal takes aim at reducing the cost of trust in usage billing in the utility sector. In developed nations this is a basic part of life and improvements here would impact a large amount of users and it intuitively makes sense. What isn't clear is just how large the cost of trust in current systems is, and how blockchain will address it, and how many users are within the targeted market. Would like to see an estimate on how much transactional friction exists, and what the biggest struggle for current utility billing is. Late payments, complex fee structures, overdrafts, inaccurate measurements, misaddressed bills all come to mind.

This proposal absolutely addresses the challenge of scaling up the DeFi ecosystem. Also, this is a great example of "real finance" or "RealFi" as described by the Cardano team. We are not looking for yield farming or how to make a quick 10x, but actual real world decentralized financial solutions. Paying monthly bills is a chore everyone can relate to and those $3-$5 service fees add up over time. The proposal is well crafted with copious details and full cost breakdown, however I do believe you might be a little optimistic and will explain what I mean in the next section.

The problem and solution are reasonable, the proposal can be related to DeFi, but the plan and goals established don't make clear the impact of the proposal on the challenge, in fact everything that has been described indicates that the proposal will deliver a proof of concept in the first 6 months and this doesn't demonstrate a significant impact on the metrics established in the challenge brief.

There is no technical documentation or WP included in this proposal and the timeline included says the dApp won't go live for 12 months, this is uncompetitive. This is also not DeFi if you need to rely on government utility depts/billing agencies that is CeFi.
Project may be a good DeFi project in its own right,, but does not meet the challenge of Scaling up the DeFi ecosystem in Cardano.

"DeFi Billing" is strongly aligned both with the "Scale-up Cardano's DeFi Ecosystem" and the overall focus of the Cardano community on providing services that individuals, corporations, and governments can benefit from.

The experience and plan presented is complete with funding details. However, more development around the problem that the AP/AR office faces would bring clarity to the plan and reduce risk of applying a great solution to the wrong problem. The proposal identifies this complexity risk, but doesn't identify how it will be reduced.

40 years of experience as a developer, IT project, and programmer manager tells me you have seen software grow and evolve since it infancy. The proposal mentions the complexity of the problems you are attempting to solve. I think you do a great job of recognizing the problem and the potential for mass adoption with stating "literally attract billions of Defi users." My concern is with this next statement. "Initially I expect a lot of solution help and developer support from the Cardano development community with the SME skills needed to delve deep into how this solution could work." This seems like a big if so what if you receive funding but that support is not available? I think it would be wise to continue making contacts in the blockchain development community so that you will be ready to go once funding is secured. Also, on that note I would like to see more information about the rest of your team.

The statement "I cant pretend to understand the full details of this as yet and there are no doubt many options that can be explored." demonstrates that the proposal still needs to be more refined.

Creating DeFi dapp involves complexity in the development of smart contracts, introducing an element of integrating DeFi with CeFi increases the complexity of the project.

The dependence on an oracle creates additional complexity, as currently there is no reliable oracle model on Cardano's blockchain and options would have to be studied / developed which would decrease the feasibility of the proposal in the next 6 months.

The budget for the proposal was set at $ 323,290 and half the amount ($ 161,645) was requested as a fund for Catalyst. The remaining half will need alternative methods of funding, an ICO can be an alternative method. I believe that the budget is not reasonable, as there are fundamental aspects about the plan that are still unclear and this creates doubts about the definition of the budget. The fact that the requested amount fund only half of the development compromises the auditability the proposal.

Compliance and regulation risks were not considered and this is a key aspect to assess the feasibility of the proposal. Integrating DeFi with government-related systems is a major challenge and projects could take years to establish a framework. IOG's own partnership with the government of Ethiopia demonstrated the great difficulty in inserting solutions created in public blockchains to the government. When observing the development of blockchain-related technologies by governments out there, the delay of governments in the development of CBDCs is notable and the bureaucracy involved in the process makes integration difficult. In addition, there is a great preference for governments to use private blockchains. These risks need to be taken into account as they bring risks to the proposal's success and there is still no plan that demonstrates how this type of risks will be faced.

The use of blockchain for bill payment brings additional risks to users' privacy, and there is still no private computing solution available at Cardano. The lack of privacy in these transactions can bring risks to users of this model, because when making payments the user exposes his balance.

Receiving payments in ADA implies that the recipient will have to deal with volatility. There is still no decentralized option for converting ADA, as until July (until Alonzo HFC) there will be no DEXs and stable coins on Cardano, which creates friction in this model. This could be circumvented by using someone to take custody (centralized exchanges) but it would go against the purpose of DeFi and in the opposite direction to the basic concepts of DeFi, which deal with removing intermediaries, removing trust and bringing more costs.

There is no way to verify the experience of the proposer beyond the "relevant experience", no GH links, no demo app/website. The roadmap is also for 12 months out for go-live, given the requested budget 1 year out is way too long to have a production dApp.

Detailed budget provided, but there is not a detailed execution plan. It opwuld be good to have some evidence of the experience of the proposer (LinkedIn Profile?), especially given the size of the funding request.

A very detailed plan is provided which provides confidence that the project will be successfully implemented. The first month is focused on identifying partners and developers, which creates a significant risk for the project. If a least one customer and one technical partner had been included as part of the proposal development, the probability of success would be significantly higher.
The proposal doesn't identify a measureable to assess progress against but it does set the goal to have 1 working partnership.

The proposer provides a clear and well articulated plan for how to develop and implement this project. The proposal present a timeline with goals and metrics up to 6 months. The cost breakdown is also accountant able for the 6 months of potential development. I understand the 6 month timeline comes from the mission of scaling up DeFi in that window, but I would like to know more about what happens once/if mass adoption for Adabillr is live. I would have liked to see more details about where the other $161,645 is expected to come from since you are only requesting half of the budgeted amount. I believe this idea/project has the potential to be very profitable so please consider a way you could share profit back into the Catalyst fund. Making the ICO a governance token is clever and increases accountability for the system you are attempting to build.

The budget for the proposal was set at $ 323,290 and half the amount ($ 161,645) was requested as a fund for Catalyst. The remaining half will need alternative methods of funding, an ICO can be an alternative method. I believe that the budget is not reasonable, as there are fundamental aspects about the plan that are still unclear and this creates doubts about the definition of the budget. The fact that the requested amount fund only half of the development compromises the auditability the proposal.

Considering that the requested budget corresponds to more than 50% of the amount available in the budget for this challenge, it is crucial that there are details to indicate whether these values make sense. Although there are details about the allocation of resources (mostly staff costs) the lack of a technical development plan makes it difficult to assess the budget and allow auditability.

Positions like Crypto Soln Architect, UX designer, Team Lead, Business Lead, testers have been described as part of the development of dapp, but there are no details on the development of the PoC dapp itself, which compromises auditability of the budget in relation to the staff costs.

There are no KPIs. The roadmap establishes some goals, but these are vague and not very objective, which hinders the ability to auditability.

In general, the proposal describes a valid problem, but one that requires a complex solution, due to technical factors and difficulty in integration with centralized government systems, which increases technical complexity and inserts compliance and regulatory elements.

The proposal needs further refinement to indicate feasibility and auditability.

This is not a DeFi solution at all, its CeFi using Cardano smart contracts, the implementation risk is also massive: there is a reason governments use "expensive inflexible insecure solutions", it's because they know they work and have been hardened for years. The proposal plan and roadmap also leaves a lot of open questions: who are the developer resources? why does it take 12 months to fully develop this dApp? Please include technical docs or a White Paper to describe this solution in detail.
No metrics or KPI's provided, especially on how the project meets the goal of scaling up the DeFi ecosystem within the next 6 months.

The proposal provides very specific information regarding the allocation of funds over a six month plan. The budget ($323,290) is higher than the requested funds ($161,645). The proposal indirectly suggests that an ICO will be used to cover this gap; however, that seems to be a risky assumption in such a short period of time. Nevertheless, given the extensive details provided, the proposer has clearly defined the objectives and measures of success.

solution: Propose to develop a **billing smart contract solution** targeting use cases around initially Utilities billing. Calling it "adabillr" or Billr
experience: I have been a developer and IT project and programme manager for over 40 years. Looking to lead a team of smart contract dapp devs.
